pros:
It IS a job if you're in dire straits.
There are a few good people still working there.
cons:
It is a longstanding HCA policy (the parent corp.) to keep people PRN for YEARS on end, working them full time, expecting them to take call, work holidays, etc. as if they were a permanent employee, BUT NEVER HIRE THEM PERMANENTLY WITH BENEFITS.
The hospital morale is at an all time low due to the management. 

There are many ethics violations and the 1-800 "Ethics Line" is nothing more than an internal control mechanism to keep employees from calling JCAHO, MQSA, aetcns other external hospital governing bodies. It is the TRUTH. 

Call that number and blow the whistle? They'll "investigate" by cleaning up/erasing all signs of misdeeds, declare there are no violations....and, mysteriously, the "anonymous" whistle blower is no longer employed.
Yes, that REALLY happens.

If you do make it to permanent employee status, HCA  offers sub-optimal pay and benefits; your 401k match is NOT added per pay period so the power of compound interest works for YOU all year, it's added as a lump sum in December...the company keeps all that compound interest for themselves. Which is a moot point, the turnover rate is high enough that few people are there long enough to be fully vested.

Combine this with chronic understaffing and the uncertainty of your job security (Memorial and Community hospitals are being consolidated by the end of 2018) and you have a very stressful work environment for subpar pay/benefits and a hostile work environment due to management.

It is a shame, Memorial WAS pleasant to work at BEFORE HCA bought them.
